comments.commentBody: Just to be clear: this was a problem related to Holden's original injury, not, as far as we know, related to anything that happened in his Carling Cup appearance.

"Fair enough. But that was last week."

Good for you. Some of these old birds have been limply and lamely complaining about the cultural liberals pushing out economic concerns for DECADES, without lifting a finger to build even a counter *intellectual* movement--never mind the kind of social and political infrastructure mentioned here. (I guess that grunt work is your job--no wait, you're going to get pepper sprayed and thrown in jail).

How many times can you make the same lame criticism and not even lift a finger?

You know, I bet they watched their investment portfolios the whole time.

What really got me was how many Times readers seemed to take Gina Bellafante's *column* as a straight news article. The comments thread was full of people disparaging her reporting and accusing her of bias. Well, folks, that's why we call it a column. It's a piece of opinion. I wish the Times had been more aggressive in pointing this out, as I think the insults directed at Ms. Bellafante, both by people on this site and by other media outlets mocking the Times, were harsh and inappropriate.

Yes, Occupy Wall Street is disorganized.

But, my goodness....the banks and trading houses have robbed us, and neither Congress, nor the President does a thing.

I'm just glad somebody did something, anything.

And to answer your question, it is neither carnival nor revolution.

It is an objection to the immoral, illegal status quo.

Ginia Bellafante's words, “...opportunity to air societal grievances as carnival,” and David Brook's point that, "The code isn’t just a set of rules. It’s a source of identity,"  remind me of the errant strategies of protestors in the 60's.  When clever, pointed, admired and effective street theater was replaced by "bring your guitar and dope" "be-ins", the peace movement took a hit.  The pilots have it all over the hippies when it comes to sending an effective and hopefully influential message.  And no cops hated them, because they identified with the - and their comportment - as do most Americans.  If they want to stir the widest possible audience, the Wall Street demonstrators need to sacrifice the identity codes that endear them to others of their ilk, while putting off most of the population.

I am shocked and dismayed that a leader of the ACLU has rejected the Administration's view that the man must be caught and tried in a US civilian court rather than killed. We are in a battle and when an American ciltizen becomes a combatant for the enemy in wartime, he can be aimed at and fired upon. I belong the the ACLU and i am ashamed of their hairbrained view that altho it is ok to kill  enemy combatants in combat , a citizen must be caught alive  before action is taken against him. Should we have risked our soldiers lives  and dropped them in Yemen to get him? Absurd.

While I deplored many (most) of the illegal Bush-Cheney assassination and detention activities, especially with US nationals, I don't really see the problem with this guy in terms of targeting this man or "life-taking without a trial." And certainly not in terms of his "free speech" being exercised as he advocated/plotted violence.

He CHOSE to live abroad, effectively giving up his citizenship and then overtly advocated and plotted murder and acts of terrorism and war against US citizens and others!

As the Times article itself Notes, he "joined the enemy in wartime, shifting from propaganda to an operational role in plots..."

For those that truly believe that this mans civil liberties were violated I think there may be room for debate. For those that use it as an excuse to be contrary because of their politics I say grow up!

In a few years, we might want to revisit the way this was handled...if our country is still around. Though what we did may be deserving, there is a true ugliness involved that will leave a huge imprint on all the Muslim people. And there are a lot of them, in all corners of the earth, and more very day. I wonder what affect this killing has in even his old mosque here in the USA. Do you think he is now a martyr in many of their eyes, someone they would now like to emulate...you know the answer.

"Difficult debate"??? No. I think not. If we wish to live in a democracy then we must trust the democratic process. We must trust that the process, our process, will work. It has most certainly worked in the past and we have no reason to suspect it would not have worked in this case. The United States should not ever be in the business of murdering it's own citizens. Period. But most especially never should we do so without DUE PROCESS. The rule of law is officially dead.

Dead men don't talk. A trial probably would have been embarrassing. Lawyers could easily defend this person who most likely had strong convictions. But we will never know. Maybe it's best we don't know. Maybe knowing would be too confusing for those who have little or no empathy for a person who has been classified an enemy combatant.

Wasn't much of an issue in the late 60's/early 70's when the FBI and local police in collusion, murdered dozens of black activists,the Panthers come to mind. Nowadays this would have been called extrajudicial murder.
@narthwoodsbangor, maine,,,,,, perhaps you should have given him a room and your house and no one would have known he was there.

Ok so what part of ISLAM has declared war on us don't some of you get?

The World Trade Towers falling?
The Pentagon?
These so called moderate Muslims who don't speak out?
The every day statements when asked of the muslim on the street that they are participating in Jiad against the U.S. and would like to see us destroyed?

When you are at war and citizen or not you choose to join the enemy you now are an enemy combatant.

So yes the butcher who walks into a store and murders multiple people gets due process, and I'd hit the streets in support of his right.

The traitor who goes over and fights for the enemy in wartime has as much as denounced his American citizenship so if he is caught or killed during a military op against the enemy that is his choice.

I'm fine with it

And I'm sorry if you can't see the diference.

Awlaki and most other militants use the globe as their battle field. They are very fluid and on the move constantly. Urban neighborhoods, in cities and towns, are used as their armor. The battlefield is anywhere and at anytime. The drones are racking up kill after kill and the militants can't stop them. The rate we are taking these guys out, there may be an end to their madness...the madness of terror as we know it today.

"A man walks into a drug store on Long Island, takes out a gun and in cold blood shoots 4 people..."

Your comparison is wrong; if the man in the drug store was holed up, refused to come out, and continued shooting at people, then the police would be entirely right to kill him. That is essentially what was done here.

Once he took up with the other side he ceased to become an American.  Unlike Jane Fonda who just posed with the enemy Al-Malawki, oops Awlaki actually planned attacks on Americans.  At that point he became a traitor and should have been executed by hanging.  But death by drone seems to be the popular way that Jihadists die today.  Much like cockroaches we are slowly exterminating them.  Finally I say to Al-Awlaki's Mother, how could you bring such garbage into this world.  It's too late but you should have had an abortion.  And just think how much money that drone missile costs ...

This is not a football game or a soccer match.  There are no rules. It was just 19 days ago we were all reminded why these actions are taking place.  They should not stop until all the bad guys are gone and we get to determine who they are.

Better question is why are we having this discussion-period!  This would not be a question if the person was born in another country then it would just be co-lateral damage.  If a foreign government did it then there would be all bloody hell to pay for it.

An American in name-only by virtue of being born in the US, Anwar al-Awlaki was a traitor to the country. It seems clear that he was radicalized at an early age, and although he attended college in the US and condemned the attacks on 9/11, he quickly turned against his country of birth. He desired to caused grievous damage to the United States, its citizen, its army, and its basic fabric: a distinguishing difference between petty criminals or even a common murderers who deserve due process in a court of law. Al-Awlaki was a terrorist at war with the US while living in foreign soil and has been dealt with according to a process of his own choosing. There should be no sympathy for his death.

What a bunch of hypocrites. The Republican Party runs 2 Presidential elections on the fear factor that they are the only ones capable of keeping America safe then invokes the Constitution and civil liberties when a Democratic administration takes out an avowed, engaged enemy of our State.

No shame Ron Paul and Fox News.

Apparently bureaucrats may now choose to deem US citizens to be threats and unfit to live, ending lives by merely pushing a button to activate a remote-controlled drone This is great news for the Feds who executed the "Ruby Ridge" killings, long loathed by the extreme Right; and the Philadelphia cops who dropped a bomb on the Move headquarters, an act that enraged the Left. It seems they didn't go too far, after all. Due process of law isn't really as important as those who believe in and trust the Constitution would have you think.

But before the Right and Left get too deep into celebrating, they should be careful to mind this advice" whatever you do, don't look too threatening to those bureaucrats who now have the power to kill you at will.
The world has one less murder. I couldn't be happier. War is brutal, the rule is kill or be kill. What am I missing?

Interesting debate. There was no such debate over the killing of thousands of non-US civilians who are bombed in their homes and in wedding processions in attacks carried out on other countries. US military and CIA have become the judge, the jury and the executioner at the same time. In guess the golden principle being followed here is not justice, but that might is always right.

I see an analogy here. Would people say that if a policeman sees an American citizen pointing a gun at another American citizen and shoots him to stop the gunman from killing the victim - is that wrong? But what about a trial?  Due process is not possible when a terrorist is hiding in a lawless area and is heavily guarded. This terrorist had a gun pointed at our heads and it was justified to take him out to protect his intended victims.  Seems like common sense to me.
